remarks: Pocklington's theorem, which gives a sufficient criterion for a number ` N ` to be prime.  This is the preferred method for verifying large primes, being much more efficient to compute than trial division.  This form has been optimized for application to specific large primes; see ~ pockthg for a more general closed-form version.  (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Mar-2014.)
statement:
pockthi.p $e |- P e. Prime $.
pockthi.g $e |- G e. NN $.
pockthi.m $e |- M = ( G x. P ) $.
pockthi.n $e |- N = ( M + 1 ) $.
pockthi.d $e |- D e. NN $.
pockthi.e $e |- E e. NN $.
pockthi.a $e |- A e. NN $.
pockthi.fac $e |- M = ( D x. ( P ^ E ) ) $.
pockthi.gt $e |- D < ( P ^ E ) $.
pockthi.mod $e |- ( ( A ^ M ) mod N ) = ( 1 mod N ) $.
pockthi.gcd $e |- ( ( ( A ^ G ) - 1 ) gcd N ) = 1 $.
pockthi $p |- N e. Prime $.
